About the commencement of the year, |
one day overlook my neighbour who, the
last year, practised "entire abstinence" in
the use of ardent spirits. Well, said !, are
you going to begia this year as you did the
last? Yes, said he.-But, have you enjoyed
as good health the past as you did formerly!
Yes, think better.-Did you work as well
through the hot weather? Yes, quite.-Haye

THE CATHOLIC CONGREGATION of St.
Peters Church, in the borough of Whining
ton, return their unfeigned thanks to their Ex-
celencies, the late and present Governors: and
also to the Honorable gentleme n that composed
the Senate and Assembly of the State of Della.
ware, since the year Of our Lord 1872 to this
present year of our Lord, 1897, for their kind be-
neyoence, founded on Christian philanthropy,
in extending the right hand of fellowship, to their
Catholic brethren, (not in hecting words, but in
real actions) to accomplish what was not in our
power to do; which was, to finish our church,
and pay off the membranes due on the churchi
by granting IFS lottery, and extending It, by
granting us two supplements; one OF which we
have the proceeds received by the Lottery and


first supplement; which was divided into four
different classes, and the proceeds obtained by
them, which was received by William Larkln,
Grocer in the aforesaid Borough of Wilnlngton,
who acted as principal Manager for said Lottery,
and received the several sums OF money obtain
cd by the sales of the aforesaid tour diiiefeht
classes Of said Lottery.-wh;ch money, the sad
| william Larkn Illegally holds from US, the Ma
nagcrs for the Congregation OF 81 reters
Church, although We have repeatedly called ON
the said William Larkin during thc time ana term


of nsar five wears from the commencement OF


~ e,st c.sa Of the said Lottery. And for his


so illegally Withholding the money obtained by
I'M, snles Of the aforesaid Lottery, VIC have
| su;t .t Law anainst the said William Larkin; as


we could not get settlement from him, but a.


busve language and insolence, every time we'
applied 10 him for such settlement.


I'VE, the Managers of st. Peters Church, give


the public in general notice, that we discharge
the aforesaid William Larkin from our employ
and FORBID him to transact any business as Ma


nager, Agent or Broker for any concern, direct


ly or indirectly, belonging to St. Peters Church
| i, tLa Rorounh of Wiln,inetai, state Of Dela


ware.-.And also give the prolic notice that we


will not acknowledge nor ahde by any trailsac.


ton done for the Churc.i by any person or per-


sons, unless legally empowered by the Manag


ers. -
| PETER PIERCE,
| BERNARD MWUlGEN,
! BERNARD M'CASN,
JOHN DURNlN.

The following is monkish composition,
the Latin not being classical. The word
Tumba is found in no Roman autkor. The
Epitaph runs thus:--


Hic jacet, in tumba,


Rosamundi, non Rosamunda,


Non Redolet, sed olet,


Que redolere solet.


The literal translation is: "Herc lies in
the Tomb, the rose of the world not fra
grant rose; for she who used to exale per-
fume, has now disgusting odour." In Eng
lish we might say:


Within this dark and silent tomb repose
The bones other styled the worlds fair rose;
How chang'd, alas, is Rosamond the fair
Whose fragrance once perfum'd the ambient air.
| Three removes are as bad as a fire; and
keep thy shop and thy shop will keep thee;
and again, if you would have your business
done, so; if not, send. Again,
He that by the plough would thrive,
Himself must either hold or drive.
And again, the eye of the master will do more
work than both his hands; and again, waut
of care does more damage than want of
knowledge; and again, not to oversee work.
men is 10 leave them your purse open.
Franklin.

GLEANINGS.

a.


ry joint he makes is obliquely constructed.
The same obliquity is obvious in system
building.


Sir Isaac Newton was master builder
in the systems of astronomy, fluxions, re-
fraction, &c. yet the rules he resorted to in
framing circular, oval, eliptical, octagonal,
septangular, sexangular, quadrangular, par
allelogram, crooked and straight lines; also
projectile, attractile, ,sentrepetal centrifugal,
torces Likewise, densties, causes, and eff
fccts; were demonstrated by bis own fanci-
full invention. Like myself, IN grammar
tactics, he found it impossible to square


rules, so as to tally with example, until he
hit upon the "problem of three Bodies"


This problem, chiefly made use of to recon-


cile differences, has been considered ex-


ceedingly sublime, because the most intrl-


cate that ever had been formed-requirins
head as capacious as its authors to con-


san it without cracking. 1t is true, some


of it's advocates, like the fable of the "Frog


and Ok" have had their heads expanded


to an enormous extent, in endeavoring to


find out its meaning, yet all to little purpose;


for the three bodied monster eludcs every


attempt at comprising or squarins him by


rule. And was it not fashionable and fanci-


full to belong to systems of grammar building,


plough building, and theory building, which


points out the mode of world building, it is
louat whether the arts and sciences might
not suffer decay However, some consola-


arises in believing that patent rights in dis


coveries will continue to be granted; and


sprouts will yet shoot from old stocks, when
not overshadowed by thick growth OF bod
, les, similar to the problem aforesaid, Which
problem, apprehend, by its features, has
, done injury to the science of astronomy.
Like Pompey's pillar, it is too elevated to
be climbed to its top, and too firmly cement
ed with plaster, to be easily ovcrthrown.---
Therefore, it may be considered monu
t ment Of wondcr rather than OF use. For
conceive that whatever leads man in his stu
dies of the solar system, or any other sys'
TEN, from the simplicity OF its beautiful or


der, into mysteries whose basis are hypothe-
sis alone, are injurious to the rising age, and
f may introduce, through its abettors, the
/ same bigotry in favor of irratonality, as re-
ligious tlogmas too frequently Introduce a,


mong sects. Therefore intend, should it ial


to my lot hereafter to advance IDEAS III oppo-
, sition to some others, to search fer those ma


I. Il
Y when properly analysed, may disclose fact:
y not much to be doubted. My limits in this es
q say is prescribed, and | may conclude witt
Il rcmarking, that whether our theories arr
i right or wrong, they present no obstacle e
4 the continuance Of worlds. AMEN.

object ofhis vision, its blue expanse. As stood

The President of the United States has
transmitted to Congress Message (Which
will be found in preceding column OF this
paper) relating to the differences between
che State OF Georgia and the General Gov
ernment. This message will be read with
The deepest interest, and feelings of regret,
that the actions of Gov. Troup should have
brought about this unpleasant state of things,
In regard to the Indian Territory. The Ian
suage of the President is energetic; and we
have every reason to believe that he has
taken firm stand against the pretensions
Of the Governor. What the result oi this
unpleasant business will be, time must show.
Yet, we cannot but express our decided
appreciation of the course of the Executive
The select Committee appointed on the
letter Of the Vice President, made their re-
port on Tuesday. This report acquits the
Vice President, i'll the most unequlvoca
terms Of any participation in the Mix Con
tract.

Mr.. Clopp, the owner of tho stage that caused
the accident, was driving at the time, and is said
driver in the employ of Messrs Porter & Wolfe,
and came very nigh at one time, running him up
on couple fdrays in the street. The accident
originated in his having run against the leading
horses Of the other stage, which caused them to
fly off to the pavement; and the driver, in en-
deavoring to reign them off, and keep from run
ming upon the kirb, put the wheels upon short
lock, and the stage overturned. There were
ten persons in the stage at the time the accident
occurred.

Major Caleb p. Bennett has been unani-
mously re-appointed. by the Levy Court,
Treasurer OF N. Castle county, for the en-
suing year. This will complete the twenti-
eth of a. a,.succession of years, during which
fhis Revolutionary veteran has held the Of
hce of County Treasurer.

We have before us, says the Editor OF the
Democratic Press, a most interesting letter
from an American Lady, written at LA
grange. December 6th, 1896" where she
Rad. for some time, been on a visit to the
venerable and excellent Lafayette. We have
much pleasure in submitting the following
extracts. They rub out foul calumny
which, we arc at loss 70 know upon what
authority, has been extensively circulated
against the American people.


"By the American papers | see, letter
said to be written by very respectable gen
sleman, giving an account OF a visit to La
grange among numerous errors in this pro
duction, there is one which has given Gen
eral LatuYcnc real pain. 1t is where tn,
writer SAYS, he is Informed, that nine appli
cations had been made to the General TO
money, the preceding week, by young mel
from the United States. Last night the Gen
said, with much animation, that this was a
great mistake as ever was made, and tina
he had never had single application OF tina
nature; that the Young Americans who hat
called upon him, had uniformly conducte
themselves with the greatest propriety, an
chat there was no foundation whatever for th
report


al have, says the.letter writer, seen enoug
of other parts of the world, to teach me
love my own country more, and to estimat
its advantages higher every day. Ours ma
emphatically be called the Land of Libert,
The truth is, we have no such freedom, an
SO little opportunity of contrasting our COZ
dition with other countries, that we do M
sufficiently appreciate our happiness. III
zeal for, and love of country, feel, make
me anxious that the above declaration OF OF
beloved General, may be given in refutatic
Of the libel which has been published"
A. extract of Letter from Carthagcna

Though look old, yet am strong and lusty;


For in my youth never did apply


Hot and rebcllious liquors in my blood;


Nor did with unbashful forehead WOO


The means of weakness and debility;


Therefore my age is usty winter.


Frosty but kindly. MaheSPeore'


About the commencement of the year, |
one day overlook my neighbour who, the
last year, practised "entire abstinence" in
the use of ardent spirits. Well, said !, are
you going to begia this year as you did the
last? Yes, said he.-But, have you enjoyed
as good health the past as you did formerly!
Yes, think better.-Did you work as well
through the hot weather? Yes, quite.-Haye

Peters Church, in the borough of Whining
ton, return their unfeigned thanks to their Ex-
celencies, the late and present Governors: and
also to the Honorable gentleme n that composed
the Senate and Assembly of the State of Della.
ware, since the year Of our Lord 1872 to this
present year of our Lord, 1897, for their kind be-
neyoence, founded on Christian philanthropy,
in extending the right hand of fellowship, to their
Catholic brethren, (not in hecting words, but in
real actions) to accomplish what was not in our
power to do; which was, to finish our church,
and pay off the membranes due on the churchi
by granting IFS lottery, and extending It, by
granting us two supplements; one OF which we
have the proceeds received by the Lottery and


first supplement; which was divided into four
different classes, and the proceeds obtained by
them, which was received by William Larkln,
Grocer in the aforesaid Borough of Wilnlngton,
who acted as principal Manager for said Lottery,
and received the several sums OF money obtain
cd by the sales of the aforesaid tour diiiefeht
classes Of said Lottery.-wh;ch money, the sad
| william Larkn Illegally holds from US, the Ma
nagcrs for the Congregation OF 81 reters
Church, although We have repeatedly called ON
the said William Larkin during thc time ana term


of nsar five wears from the commencement OF


~ e,st c.sa Of the said Lottery. And for his


so illegally Withholding the money obtained by
I'M, snles Of the aforesaid Lottery, VIC have
| su;t .t Law anainst the said William Larkin; as


we could not get settlement from him, but a.


busve language and insolence, every time we'
applied 10 him for such settlement.


I'VE, the Managers of st. Peters Church, give


the public in general notice, that we discharge
the aforesaid William Larkin from our employ
and FORBID him to transact any business as Ma


nager, Agent or Broker for any concern, direct


ly or indirectly, belonging to St. Peters Church
| i, tLa Rorounh of Wiln,inetai, state Of Dela


ware.-.And also give the prolic notice that we


will not acknowledge nor ahde by any trailsac.


ton done for the Churc.i by any person or per-


sons, unless legally empowered by the Manag


ers. -
| PETER PIERCE,
| BERNARD MWUlGEN,
! BERNARD M'CASN,
JOHN DURNlN.


! F.o. IA, 1927. 22--4tr,

full articles.headline: EPITAPIIS.
full articles.article:
Here lies my wife, and Heaven knows,
Not less for mine, than her repose!
IN STAvERToN CTuRCH-YARD.

who would live longer but she coulden;
Sorrow and grief made her decay,
Till her bad leg card her away
IN KINGSBRIDGE CHI RCH-YARn.

relations IN tie Church,
Here lie |, at the chancel doorl
Here lie because am poor:
The further in the more to pay;
Here lie as warm as they

,,on+ 10 o'clock last Tuesday morning, The


Aovu rart ofthe Essex, (Mass.) Merinack Bridge
chal' I,v owing, as is supposed to the effect OF

you no hankering for it when much fatigued!
No, none at ali. Food refrcshes and recruits
me more than spirit used to.--I thought his
testimony to entire abstinence ought to be
made public; for no man among US is more in
dustrious or labors harder.-Con. Obs.


The following is monkish composition,
the Latin not being classical. The word
Tumba is found in no Roman autkor. The
Epitaph runs thus:--


Hic jacet, in tumba,


Rosamundi, non Rosamunda,


Non Redolet, sed olet,


Que redolere solet.


The literal translation is: "Herc lies in
the Tomb, the rose of the world not fra
grant rose; for she who used to exale per-
fume, has now disgusting odour." In Eng
lish we might say:


Within this dark and silent tomb repose
The bones other styled the worlds fair rose;
How chang'd, alas, is Rosamond the fair
Whose fragrance once perfum'd the ambient air.
| Three removes are as bad as a fire; and
keep thy shop and thy shop will keep thee;
and again, if you would have your business
done, so; if not, send. Again,
He that by the plough would thrive,
Himself must either hold or drive.
And again, the eye of the master will do more
work than both his hands; and again, waut
of care does more damage than want of
knowledge; and again, not to oversee work.
men is 10 leave them your purse open.
Franklin.

full articles.headline: Executors Notice.
full articles.article:
All persons indebted to the Estate of JOHN
KEMP, late of Wilmington, Card-maker, dec,
are requested to make payment, and all persons
having claims on said estate, are also desired to
exhibit them duly attested, when they will be
Immediately paid.


WIN. MARSHALL.

The Lehigh Company of Pennsylvania,
report that they have taken TO market the
last year 10000 tons of coal--which is about

vet the demand is not satisfied.

city in two mails.


The coloured man who was educated at
Bowdoin College, is about to publish news
paper at N. York for the Africans.


The destitute labourers of Nova Scotia
have volunteered their winter services on
the Canal for their provisions.


The Whitehall Observer says, that the
snow on the Green Mountains is better than
six feet deep. 1t is better than feet deep
here; because it is little more than three.

There are Sc families consisting of 314

ia, to supply the vacancy occasoned by the
resignation OF Gov. Tyler, from the 4th oil
March next.

Jan

a.


ry joint he makes is obliquely constructed.
The same obliquity is obvious in system
building.


Sir Isaac Newton was master builder
in the systems of astronomy, fluxions, re-
fraction, &c. yet the rules he resorted to in
framing circular, oval, eliptical, octagonal,
septangular, sexangular, quadrangular, par
allelogram, crooked and straight lines; also
projectile, attractile, ,sentrepetal centrifugal,
torces Likewise, densties, causes, and eff
fccts; were demonstrated by bis own fanci-
full invention. Like myself, IN grammar
tactics, he found it impossible to square


rules, so as to tally with example, until he
hit upon the "problem of three Bodies"


This problem, chiefly made use of to recon-


cile differences, has been considered ex-


ceedingly sublime, because the most intrl-


cate that ever had been formed-requirins
head as capacious as its authors to con-


san it without cracking. 1t is true, some


of it's advocates, like the fable of the "Frog


and Ok" have had their heads expanded


to an enormous extent, in endeavoring to


find out its meaning, yet all to little purpose;


for the three bodied monster eludcs every


attempt at comprising or squarins him by


rule. And was it not fashionable and fanci-


full to belong to systems of grammar building,


plough building, and theory building, which


points out the mode of world building, it is
louat whether the arts and sciences might
not suffer decay However, some consola-


arises in believing that patent rights in dis


coveries will continue to be granted; and


sprouts will yet shoot from old stocks, when
not overshadowed by thick growth OF bod
, les, similar to the problem aforesaid, Which
problem, apprehend, by its features, has
, done injury to the science of astronomy.
Like Pompey's pillar, it is too elevated to
be climbed to its top, and too firmly cement
ed with plaster, to be easily ovcrthrown.---
Therefore, it may be considered monu
t ment Of wondcr rather than OF use. For
conceive that whatever leads man in his stu
dies of the solar system, or any other sys'
TEN, from the simplicity OF its beautiful or


der, into mysteries whose basis are hypothe-
sis alone, are injurious to the rising age, and
f may introduce, through its abettors, the
/ same bigotry in favor of irratonality, as re-
ligious tlogmas too frequently Introduce a,


mong sects. Therefore intend, should it ial


to my lot hereafter to advance IDEAS III oppo-
, sition to some others, to search fer those ma


I. Il
Y when properly analysed, may disclose fact:
y not much to be doubted. My limits in this es
q say is prescribed, and | may conclude witt
Il rcmarking, that whether our theories arr
i right or wrong, they present no obstacle e
4 the continuance Of worlds. AMEN.

ern, Gloucestershire, man and his wife

tance of mile. L &c woman is the balbe

MISUNDERSTANDING may be divided int
-. three classes list, Those who learn from tn


experience OF UtNefS--thcy arc HbpFy ihci
rs Cd, Those who learn from their own expt
b. rience--they are wise men;--and lastl,
i Those who learn neither from their owl


nor other peoples experence--they al


fools. Alas this class is by far the larges
mis- Professor Carter, in one ofhis last letters fro
,cr Genoa describes his visit to the birth place
e,- the Discovcrcr Of America, in the foIlowiI
- terms


al A full day was occupied in an excursion
ro- Cocoletto, the repued birth place of Chrstoph
On Columbus Although much obscurlty still han
of over the cradle of this great man, yet the Amc
- can traveller in particular, will feel satstact
SCI in visiting spot which tradition has assoclat
on with the Dscovercr of the New World. I ha
i've neither time nor inclination at present TO ent
,cc into disqusition upon the contradictory AUTH
ities in relation to this subject nor to balance I
Nie conflicting claims of rival places TO the nativ
on, of the adventurous navigator. Ills own mar
are script is now understood to be in the hands
al Washington Irving at siadrid, who perhaps II
throw some new light upon the early years OF
ue- author.


cen The village of Cocoletto is situated at
lus head of the Gulf, about fifteen miles from Gen
,r, on the road towards Savona. On arriving at


49,, little hotel, inquiry was made for the house
ded Christopher Columbus; and some half doz
than ls.fl4

object ofhis vision, its blue expanse. As stood
leaning over the balustrade, watching the swells
breaking at my feet, and the line of little boats
moored along the beach, incredulity for mo-
ment vanished, and imagination pictured the ju-
venile navigator, launching his adventurous bark,
and sporting with that element, which was des-
tined to conduct him to imperishable renown.

The President of the United States has
transmitted to Congress Message (Which
will be found in preceding column OF this
paper) relating to the differences between
che State OF Georgia and the General Gov
ernment. This message will be read with
The deepest interest, and feelings of regret,
that the actions of Gov. Troup should have
brought about this unpleasant state of things,
In regard to the Indian Territory. The Ian
suage of the President is energetic; and we
have every reason to believe that he has
taken firm stand against the pretensions
Of the Governor. What the result oi this
unpleasant business will be, time must show.
Yet, we cannot but express our decided
appreciation of the course of the Executive
The select Committee appointed on the
letter Of the Vice President, made their re-
port on Tuesday. This report acquits the
Vice President, i'll the most unequlvoca
terms Of any participation in the Mix Con
tract.

And lets the stream of his revenge run clear"


In the Gazette of the second instant, !
the Editor takes occasion to reiterate an
assertion respecting tha circulation of this
paper, which, had VIC not some charity
for his deficiency of common sense, VIC
should do him the justice to pronounce
an objectionable falsehood. His object in
repeating an assertion which he we'll knows
is entitled to this epithet is not unknown to
us, neither does it excite surprise i; and we
| hope those into whose hands his sheet may
chance TO fall will credit him as We have
doue, 1t is not expected that certain mem


bcrs Of Congress, to whom IT is said the ga


zette is pratuHousiy Distributed, should be


as well acquainted with the gcntleman's


character as those who know him; conse-


quently, where he is most desirous the as


sertion should be believed, he will be likely


to find those who will, (if the thing is at all


noticet) through ignorance of the facts, give
it crcdcncc.


1t is Of but little consequence to us what
Mr.. Harker may say or publish relative to


the limited circulation Of this paper HIS
motive for doing so, as we have said. swell
known. That he prints more papers than


VIC do, has never been disputed; but that the
, excess Of copies subscribed for, exceeds sew
enty or eighty more than this paper, we do,
upon good authority, deny any thing he


Al. ot,u;t |, ct luIiur IN


he disputes what we have said (since he


makes it a matter OF such high Import we
will count subscribers with him, and proclaim


the result.


If Mr.. Harkcr boasts Of the wide crcula-
+ ton of the Gazette, we can do the same OF
\ that of the Wilmingtoniah, and say with
. truth, that it circulatcs through good por-
; tion of the Union, and has extended, to SN6-
/ acribcrS, from the British Province OF Up
i pcr Canada, to the State Of n. Carolina, aud
u u even to the River La Plata in South America
a and if evidence of this factis required by any


other than the Editor of the Gazette, we can
h give the names Of the gentlemen who have
o received and vet continue to receive II
:, as above stated We do not wish to boas
'. of the circulation Of this paper-that woult
d be initiating man to whom we wish t.
: bear no resemblance in such things Bu
- we would ask, docs this look like con
IS tracted circulation? does this look like be
IT ing hardly known beyond the limits OF tAi
u" borough, We will assert without fear o


~. A.. l,nt fIa t1ntr n
T this paper is as good in ths State as that Q


the Gazette, excepting the lower county


where, however, it is generally believed h
sends more papers than there are subscriber
. stantial patronage--not upon Private chGr
ii ~!


TT, Two objects this gentleman has in view, whe
n he grows bold as TO advance assertions OF tn
IL kind namely to lessen the character Of this pap
ch il the estimation of those few who have but sc
,f- dom read it--consequently, have not formed


opinion Of its merits-and, if possible, 10 ntr


duce the Gazette to notice, on the floor OF Co
as gress The first act we excuse--lt is one
ch those outporngs of malicious heart which 81
,is dom lets an opportunity pass that can be CO
on veted to bad purpose. The second, we ha
W. no objection to--considcring it another eviden
IL, of consummate egotsm. Nothing would tlcl
:. the vanity of the Corporal-we beg his pardc
- NotQry-more, than TO hear that the Delawa


Gazette has been noticed by some speech ms
o. ing gentleman of the "oppostion his {
- plorable case of 'erciuSion" should have be
w made the subject of single remark by some i
'"' ty croaker against the anathcmatized Secrets
ohs Or that the Gazette should have been coupl
MS with the Kentucky Argus, and two or three o
Nv, ers, whose names have been brought forward
lea unhappy ''out of favor" presses, who have
We. graciously been denied the bounty of the n


whom they have ;'uoceatty denounced as "'
the worst individual in the whole community
re- man without principle" 'utterly devoid OF p'
the lie confdence"-s'a political aspirant"-and
cal hundred other pretty names; such an event,
on say, would please the gentleman prod'giou'


hut unhappy, this "faithful and fearless pal

full articles.headline: Attention Lafayette Guards!
full articles.article:
A meeting of the company will be held at
VOLTS Hotel, on Saturday evening next at g
o'clock-Punctual attendance of the members is
particularly requested, and those desirous OF be.
coming members; as business of Importance Will
be laid before them.


By order fthe Commandant


JOHN SPRINGER, o. S.
HTlmington, Feb. 18th 1927.

Barsto@ Of smyrna, Del aud Miss Trottcr from

Mr.. Clopp, the owner of tho stage that caused
the accident, was driving at the time, and is said
driver in the employ of Messrs Porter & Wolfe,
and came very nigh at one time, running him up
on couple fdrays in the street. The accident
originated in his having run against the leading
horses Of the other stage, which caused them to
fly off to the pavement; and the driver, in en-
deavoring to reign them off, and keep from run
ming upon the kirb, put the wheels upon short
lock, and the stage overturned. There were
ten persons in the stage at the time the accident
occurred.

full articles.article:
Major Caleb p. Bennett has been unani-
mously re-appointed. by the Levy Court,
Treasurer OF N. Castle county, for the en-
suing year. This will complete the twenti-
eth of a. a,.succession of years, during which
fhis Revolutionary veteran has held the Of
hce of County Treasurer.

full articles.headline: A. extract of Letter from Carthagcna
full articles.article:
An extract OF Letter IRON CarthaScna,
dated the 10Th of January says


"On the 10th January, 135 sailors arrived
ber,. from New York--thcy were sent by
rommandant Jean Forse Pooby, who is also
sxnertcd with 100 more-Ihe Venezuela
srp,te sailed for Chagres on the 14th to
hiring over $50 more who had arrived there
sron, the Pacific. When these arrive, the
columbian Navy will be equipped and put
Under the command Of Admiral lllingrit, to
cruize in quest of the Spanish Squadron"


We have before us, says the Editor OF the
Democratic Press, a most interesting letter
from an American Lady, written at LA
grange. December 6th, 1896" where she
Rad. for some time, been on a visit to the
venerable and excellent Lafayette. We have
much pleasure in submitting the following
extracts. They rub out foul calumny
which, we arc at loss 70 know upon what
authority, has been extensively circulated
against the American people.


"By the American papers | see, letter
said to be written by very respectable gen
sleman, giving an account OF a visit to La
grange among numerous errors in this pro
duction, there is one which has given Gen
eral LatuYcnc real pain. 1t is where tn,
writer SAYS, he is Informed, that nine appli
cations had been made to the General TO
money, the preceding week, by young mel
from the United States. Last night the Gen
said, with much animation, that this was a
great mistake as ever was made, and tina
he had never had single application OF tina
nature; that the Young Americans who hat
called upon him, had uniformly conducte
themselves with the greatest propriety, an
chat there was no foundation whatever for th
report


al have, says the.letter writer, seen enoug
of other parts of the world, to teach me
love my own country more, and to estimat
its advantages higher every day. Ours ma
emphatically be called the Land of Libert,
The truth is, we have no such freedom, an
SO little opportunity of contrasting our COZ
dition with other countries, that we do M
sufficiently appreciate our happiness. III
zeal for, and love of country, feel, make
me anxious that the above declaration OF OF
beloved General, may be given in refutatic
Of the libel which has been published"

full articles.headline: MARRIED.
full articles.article:
On Thursday evening last. near Newark (Del.)
by the Rev. A. X. Russell, Mr. JAMES HoDGsoN,
of Chester County, (Pa.) to Miss ELIZABETH GIL
LEsrir, of New Castle County, (Del)
